title: Jeremiah 29:11 Quiz
description: Test your knowledge of Jeremiah 29:11 — God's promise of hope and a future — and its context in Jeremiah's letter to the Jewish exiles in Babylon.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 29:11, what kind of thoughts does God say He thinks toward His people?
options: Thoughts of peace, and not of evil
Thoughts of judgment and wrath
Thoughts of prosperity and wealth
Thoughts of war and vengeance
questions.correctAnswer: Thoughts of peace, and not of evil
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 29:11 (KJV) says: 'For I know the thoughts that I think toward you, saith the LORD, thoughts of peace, and not of evil, to give you an expected end.' God's intentions toward His exiled people were for their ultimate good.

questions.question: Who was Jeremiah writing to when he penned the words of Jeremiah 29:11?
options: The Jewish exiles carried away captive to Babylon
The Israelites wandering in the wilderness
The remaining people in Jerusalem
The Samaritans in the northern kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: The Jewish exiles carried away captive to Babylon
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 29:1 tells us this was a letter sent to 'the residue of the elders which were carried away captives, and to the priests, and to the prophets, and to all the people whom Nebuchadnezzar had carried away captive from Jerusalem to Babylon.'

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 29:10, how many years would the Babylonian captivity last before God would bring His people back?
options: 70 years
40 years
100 years
50 years
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 29:10 states: 'For thus saith the LORD, That after seventy years be accomplished at Babylon I will visit you, and perform my good word toward you, in causing you to return to this place.' The 70-year prophecy was fulfilled precisely.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 29:11 was originally written as a personal promise to every individual believer for immediate prosperity.
options: True
False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 29:11 was originally written to the nation of Israel in Babylonian exile. While the principle of God's sovereign goodness applies broadly, the verse was not a promise of instant prosperity. It promised restoration after 70 years of captivity — a long period of suffering came first.

questions.question: What did Jeremiah instruct the exiles to do while in Babylon?
options: Build houses, plant gardens, marry, and seek the peace of the city
Fast and weep until God delivered them
Rebel against Nebuchadnezzar and fight for freedom
Refuse to participate in Babylonian society
questions.correctAnswer: Build houses, plant gardens, marry, and seek the peace of the city
questions.explanation: In Jeremiah 29:5-7, God told the exiles to settle down in Babylon: 'Build ye houses, and dwell in them; and plant gardens, and eat the fruit of them; take ye wives...and seek the peace of the city whither I have caused you to be carried away captives.'

questions.question: Which false prophet in Jeremiah 28 broke a yoke off Jeremiah's neck and falsely predicted a quick return from Babylon within two years?
options: Hananiah
Shemaiah
Balaam
Zedekiah
questions.explanation: Hananiah the false prophet contradicted Jeremiah by breaking the wooden yoke off his neck and declaring that within two full years God would bring back the temple vessels and the exiles (Jeremiah 28:2-3, 10-11). God judged Hananiah with death that same year (Jeremiah 28:16-17).

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 29:12-13, what will happen when the exiles seek God with all their heart?
options: They shall call upon God and pray, and He will hearken; they shall seek and find Him
God will immediately destroy Babylon
They will receive double their former wealth
Angels will appear and deliver them
questions.correctAnswer: They shall call upon God and pray, and He will hearken; they shall seek and find Him
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 29:12-13: 'Then shall ye call upon me, and ye shall go and pray unto me, and I will hearken unto you. And ye shall seek me, and find me, when ye shall search for me with all your heart.' This is a conditional promise tied to wholehearted seeking.

questions.question: True or False: The false prophets in Babylon were telling the exiles to settle down for a long captivity.
options: True
False
questions.explanation: The false prophets were doing the opposite — they were promising a quick return to Jerusalem. Jeremiah warned the exiles not to listen to them (Jeremiah 29:8-9), because God had decreed a 70-year captivity. Jeremiah, not the false prophets, told them to settle down.

questions.question: What does 'an expected end' (KJV) or 'a future and a hope' mean in Jeremiah 29:11?
options: A hopeful outcome that God has planned and the people can confidently anticipate
The end of the world as prophesied in Revelation
An immediate escape from all suffering
A guarantee of earthly riches and fame
questions.correctAnswer: A hopeful outcome that God has planned and the people can confidently anticipate
questions.explanation: The Hebrew 'acharith v'tikvah' literally means 'an end and a hope' or 'a future and a hope.' It refers to the outcome God had planned for Israel — not instant relief, but the assured culmination of His good purpose after the period of discipline was complete.

questions.question: Which Babylonian king carried the Jews into captivity, fulfilling the judgment Jeremiah had prophesied?
options: Nebuchadnezzar
Cyrus
Darius
Belshazzar
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 29:1 identifies Nebuchadnezzar as the king who carried away the captives from Jerusalem to Babylon. He besieged Jerusalem multiple times (605, 597, and 586 BC), deporting Jews in waves.

questions.question: Complete this phrase from Jeremiah 29:11 (KJV): 'For I know the thoughts that I think toward you, saith the LORD, thoughts of peace, and not of evil, to give you an expected ___.'
questions.explanation: The full KJV text of Jeremiah 29:11: 'For I know the thoughts that I think toward you, saith the LORD, thoughts of peace, and not of evil, to give you an expected end.' The word 'end' (Hebrew: acharith) means outcome, future, or latter end.

questions.question: Why is it a misapplication to use Jeremiah 29:11 as a prosperity gospel proof text?
options: Because the original context was a promise of restoration after 70 years of suffering in exile, not a guarantee of immediate comfort
Because the verse is not actually in the Bible
Because it was written only for priests, not laypeople
Because the Old Testament does not apply to Christians at all
questions.correctAnswer: Because the original context was a promise of restoration after 70 years of suffering in exile, not a guarantee of immediate comfort
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 29:11 is often quoted out of context to promise instant blessing. In reality, it was spoken to people in the middle of divine judgment (Babylonian exile). The promise was that God's plan would be fulfilled — but only after 70 years of captivity. God's good plan included suffering before restoration.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah was a popular prophet whom the people and leaders of Judah eagerly listened to.
options: True
False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah was deeply unpopular. He was beaten, imprisoned, thrown into a cistern, and rejected by kings, priests, false prophets, and the people because his message of judgment and submission to Babylon was unwelcome (Jeremiah 20:2, 37:15, 38:6).

questions.question: What did God warn the exiles about the false prophets and diviners among them in Babylon?
options: Do not let them deceive you, and do not listen to the dreams they encourage you to have
Follow them, for they speak truth
They are trustworthy but should be heard cautiously
Give them offerings to support their ministry
questions.correctAnswer: Do not let them deceive you, and do not listen to the dreams they encourage you to have
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 29:8-9: 'For thus saith the LORD of hosts, the God of Israel; Let not your prophets and your diviners, that be in the midst of you, deceive you, neither hearken to your dreams which ye cause to be dreamed. For they prophesy falsely unto you in my name: I have not sent them, saith the LORD.'

questions.question: Complete this verse from Jeremiah 29:13 (KJV): 'And ye shall seek me, and find me, when ye shall search for me with all your ___.'
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 29:13 (KJV): 'And ye shall seek me, and find me, when ye shall search for me with all your heart.' This promise of finding God is conditional upon wholehearted, sincere seeking — not casual or half-hearted effort.
